Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in rejecting credibility and failing to analyze objective risk of persecution
Evidence_Assessment: Applicant's testimony, evidence of ethnic violence in Iraq
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to establish well-founded fear of persecution
Credibility_Factor: Unreasonable rejection of applicant's credibility by the Board
Legal_Rule: Credibility findings are entitled to deference unless patently unreasonable; Section 97 of IRPA requires assessment of objective risk even if credibility is questioned
Procedural_Issue: Failure to provide adequate reasons for credibility findings and lack of analysis on objective risk
Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of tribal revenge and ethnic violence in Iraq
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Board failed to conduct fair and complete analysis
Key_Evidence_Considered: Applicant's testimony, country condition evidence on Iraq
Applicant_Challenge: Board’s adverse credibility finding and omission in assessing objective risk
Court_Result: Decision set aside, claim referred to a different panel
Evidence_Type: Testimonial evidence, documentary evidence on country conditions
Remedy_Requested: Allow judicial review and refer claim back for redetermination
Outcome: Remanded for redetermination by a different panel
Resolution_Mechanism: Judicial review followed by referral to new Board panel
Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court
Governing_Rule: Credibility assessments must not be patently unreasonable; objective basis for fear must be analyzed regardless of credibility
